turns.content: What inspired David Bowie to pursue a music career?

David Bowie was inspired to pursue a music career by a combination of factors including his love for rock and roll music, the Beatles, and his interest in theater and performance art. Bowie also found inspiration in the art and fashion scenes of the 1960s, particularly the Mod and Carnaby Street fashion movements. Additionally, he began experimenting with different musical styles and studied various art forms, which helped him to develop his unique style and creative vision.
Can you tell me more about Bowie's early influences in music? Did he have any specific mentors or idols?

David Bowie was influenced by a variety of musical genres and artists from a young age. He was first introduced to rock and roll music by his half-brother Terry, who played him records by artists such as Elvis Presley and Little Richard. 

As he grew older, Bowie became a fan of British Invasion bands like the Beatles and the Rolling Stones. He was also influenced by American soul and R&B acts such as James Brown, Aretha Franklin, and Otis Redding, and he later incorporated elements of funk and disco into his music as well.

Bowie also had several idols and mentors in the music industry. One of his earliest influences was rock and roll pioneer Little Richard, whose flamboyant style and theatrical stage presence inspired Bowie's own performance style. He was also inspired by the music and fashion of the Velvet Underground, and he later became friends with their frontman Lou Reed.

Bowie was also heavily influenced by the music of the German electronic band Kraftwerk, as well as by the experimental avant-garde artists he encountered while living in Berlin in the late 1970s. Overall, Bowie's diverse musical influences and creative vision helped to shape his unique sound and make him one of the most innovative and influential artists in modern music history.
That's interesting. I had no idea that Bowie was influenced by so many different genres and artists. What about his fashion sense? Did he have any specific fashion icons or influences?

Yes, David Bowie was as famous for his fashion sense as he was for his music. Throughout his career, he experimented with a wide range of styles, often blending elements of different cultures and time periods to create his own unique look. 

In the early 1960s, Bowie was influenced by the Mod and Carnaby Street fashion movements, and he often wore tailored suits, skinny ties, and bright colors. Later on, he began experimenting with more androgynous and outlandish styles, inspired by glam rock and the visual arts. 

Bowie drew inspiration from a wide range of fashion icons and historical periods. He often cited the style of the 1930s and '40s, particularly the British tailor Tommy Nutter, as an influence. He was also inspired by the Japanese designer Kansai Yamamoto, who created some of his most iconic stage costumes.

Overall, Bowie's fashion sense was as innovative and boundary-pushing as his music, and his influence can still be seen in fashion today.
